Question_1.Context: In the context of compositionally complex alloys, the concept of dislocation pinning by atomic-scale obstacles is important for understanding material strength.
Question_1.Question: What is the primary mechanism by which atomic-scale obstacles increase the flow stress in compositionally complex alloys?
Question_1.B: By creating local stress fluctuations due to misfit strains
Question_1.Source: the group of W. Curtin has demonstrated that pinning of dislocations in compositionally complex alloys and the associated flow stress increase can to a large extent be explained in terms of the significant local stress fluctuations introduced by the superposition of misfit strains associated with atomic species of significantly different atomic radius.

Question_2.Context: The theory of dislocation pinning involves the interaction of dislocations with atomic-scale obstacles, which is relevant to the mechanical properties of alloys.
Question_2.Question: What is the role of the shear modulus in the context of dislocation as an elastic line?
Question_2.A: It determines the electrical conductivity of the dislocation line
Question_2.B: It is inversely proportional to the line tension of the dislocation
Question_2.C: It is directly proportional to the line tension of the dislocation
Question_2.D: It has no significant role in the dislocation line tension
Question_2.Source: We envisage the dislocation as an elastic line of line tension 0 b2 where is the shear modulus, b the length of the Burgers vector, and the numerical parameter 0 which is of the order of 1 may depend logarithmically on geometrical parameters characterizing the line shape.

Question_3.Context: The behavior of dislocations in alloys can be described by statistical theories, which take into account the random distribution of atomic-scale obstacles.
Question_3.Question: What is the correlation function used for in the context of dislocation behavior in alloys?
Question_3.A: To measure the electrical resistance of the dislocation line
Question_3.B: To calculate the thermal conductivity of the dislocation
Question_3.C: To determine the spatial correlations of the internal shear stress field
Question_3.D: To evaluate the optical properties of the dislocation
Question_3.Source: The random internal shear stress x, y has the correlation function x, y x , y 2 x x a , y y a . For a random alloy, the magnitude 2 can be related to the average of the squared atomic misfit.

Question_4.Context: In the study of dislocations in alloys, the concept of an effective medium is used to represent the alloy's behavior under stress.
Question_4.Question: What does the effective medium in an alloy typically contain?
Question_4.B: A random distribution of interstitial atoms
Question_4.C: A random distribution of dilatation and compression centers
Question_4.D: A uniform distribution of alloying elements
Question_4.Source: It has been suggested that this problem can be addressed by treating the alloy as an effective medium containing a random distribution of dilatation and compression centers representing the volumetric misfit of atoms of different species.

Question_5.Context: The mechanical properties of high entropy alloys are influenced by the behavior of dislocations within the material.
Question_5.Question: What is the effect of a random distribution of dilatation and compression centers on the mean square stresses in an alloy?
Question_5.A: It decreases the mean square stresses
Question_5.B: It has no effect on the mean square stresses
Question_5.C: It increases the mean square stresses
Question_5.D: It only affects the tensile stresses
Question_5.Source: The mean square stresses arising from such a random distribution can be calculated analytically, their spatial correlations are strongly anisotropic and exhibit long-range tails with third-order power law decay.

Question_6.Context: The interaction of dislocations with the stress field created by atomic misfit is a key factor in understanding the mechanical properties of alloys.
Question_6.Question: What is the typical scale parameter used to characterize the distribution of volumetric strain around an atom in an alloy?
Question_6.Source: The characteristic length a arises in the treatment of Geslin et. al. as a regularization length that characterizes the distribution of the volumetric strain around the atom position.

Question_7.Context: The mechanical strength of alloys can be affected by the volumetric misfit introduced by different atomic species.
Question_7.Question: What is the mean square volumetric strain in an alloy related to?
Question_7.A: The atomic volume and the mean square atomic misfit
Question_7.B: The atomic radius and the crystal structure
Question_7.C: The Burgers vector length and the shear modulus
Question_7.D: The dislocation density and the grain size
Question_7.Source: The mean square internal shear stress in an arbitrary plane is given by 2 Va 2 30 3 2a3 where Va is the atomic volume, 2 is the mean square volumetric strain (dilatation or compression) introduced by an individual atom into the effective medium constituted by the random alloy.

Question_8.Context: The behavior of dislocations in alloys is influenced by the spatial distribution of atomic-scale obstacles, which can be described by correlation functions.
Question_8.Question: What is the behavior of the correlation functions for the fluctuating shear stress in an effective medium with random volumetric misfit?
Question_8.A: They are isotropic and exhibit short-range tails
Question_8.B: They are anisotropic and exhibit long-range tails
Question_8.C: They are isotropic and exhibit exponential decay
Question_8.D: They are anisotropic and exhibit exponential growth
Question_8.Source: The correlation functions are plotted in Fig. 1 which shows the anisotropic nature of the correlations. The corresponding correlation integrals, which are needed to evaluate pinning parameters, are given by...

Question_9.Context: In the context of dislocation theory, the pinning of dislocations by atomic-scale obstacles is a phenomenon that can influence the mechanical properties of materials.
Question_9.Question: What is the critical resolved shear stress (CRSS) in the context of dislocation pinning?
Question_9.A: The stress required to initiate a phase transformation
Question_9.B: The stress required to move dislocations without thermal activation
Question_9.C: The stress at which the material yields under compression
Question_9.D: The stress at which the material becomes superconductive
Question_9.Source: Finally, the critical shear stress is estimated by equating the pinning energy to the work done by the external shear stress in moving the dislocation over the pinning displacement wp: ext,c Ep bwp...

Question_10.Context: The mechanical behavior of high entropy alloys is significantly influenced by the pinning of dislocations.
Question_10.Question: What is the effect of the anisotropy of shear stresses created by an assembly of compression/dilatation centers on the pinning of dislocations?
Question_10.A: It leads to reduced pinning of screw relative to edge dislocations
Question_10.B: It increases the pinning of screw dislocations only
Question_10.C: It has no effect on the pinning of dislocations
Question_10.D: It decreases the overall strength of the alloy
Question_10.Source: Our calculations demonstrate that, in addition to well known line tension effects which lead to reduced pinning of screw relative to edge dislocations, the anisotropy of shear stresses created by an assembly of compression/dilatation centers has a major influence on the anisotropic pinning of dislocations.
